reviewText:
The basis of this game is to take over planets, and then using those planets to build up more jets to take over planets with, and to eventually overwhelm your enemy with your jet ships to eliminate them.  You really only need the mouse to play.  You take over planets by clicking on them.

This seems quite cool.  However, amongst all the awesomeness that is this game, the controls feel laggy.  When I click on a planet, I don't immediately get a response from my allied planets.  And I feel in a game that requires those split decision making choices, it allows my strategy to easily fold.  I am suddenly clicking on one planet.  The exact controls are also slightly vague.  It took me a second to figure out how to upgrade, but the reasons for doing so felt almost pointless.  I could either send out ships to take over planets, or spend time upgrading them.

Overall a good game.  I have better games on my game list of 200 games, but this one is still pretty good.  It just needs some touch ups from the developer.  I felt there was too much useless information on the screen as well, and the important information was placed on the same level as some of the useless stuff.  I am really on the fence with this game, but I am recommending it out of the hopes that other people will see the positives come from the negatives.

reviewText:
This games premise is simple, so if your looking for something super complex it's not here. Strategy and tactics do exist though as taking which planet and when to attack and when to defend becomes extremely critical. One move can cost you a planet and sometimes if your not quick enough to react, the game.

The premise is your a certain colony of either humans or robots, and you start conquering worlds one by one. Some battles can take place with one or up to three AI's. Of course, each sector is it's own game, so don't look to go Star Wars and try to conquer an entire galaxy. You start the game, and you are able to choose linearly which sector to attack next. Once you are at the in-game screen, the battle begins. Planets can be upgraded and can be selected to either defend or allow for attacks. Some planets when properly upgraded have some self defense mechanisms... although I wouldn't highly rely on it. Game types vary (which is always a good idea in any game) where one game may be domination where you need to take ALL planets whereas another game may have to do with monetary means to win - meaning more money you have the more powerful your units are. Send an attack wave to an enemy planet though and watch your assets freeze as your at war. Small divot game-types such as these keep the game interesting and want you to play more.

This game is good, however NOT RECOMMENDED FOR EVERYONE! If you like space games and a casual indie territory take-over game this may be for you. If your looking for Star Trek Online keep it movin'!

Meh. I bought this for a dollar and I'm glad I didn't pay more for it. I didn't really enjoy playing it.

I didn't enjoy the game play mechanic very much. As the humans (the main campaign team), you don't gain income when attacking. While I understand that it's meant to penalize constant attacking, I found it annoying. I would have preferred to have more control over my ships, rather than just directing them to a specific planet.

The difficulty level in the later missions is way too high, apparently due to lack of playtesting (apparently the devs didn't have anyone outside the company give it a try). The campaign missions put you at a huge disadvantage and trying to beat the AI is more frustrating than challenging. Maybe the multiplayer would be more fun (playing against a human instead of the AI).

I'm not a big fan of the graphics. I find it looks garish and cartoony, though I do see what they were going for. I feel like this type of game is better when the art is more abstract. I experienced a lot of random slow-downs for no apparent reason when playing the campaign, which was irritating.

I wouldn't recommend this game.

reviewText:
While clearly inspired by Galcon, Planet's Under Attack adds some much needed depth to the formula. Your planets produce units as in Galcon but attacking requires money. While you attack you don't generate money. Also, the closer you are to your money cap, the more powerful your ships are. Also, sending ships to defend a planet you already control costs nothing. This creates a wonderful risk/reward balance where you want to commit to attacks you can win, and only with just enough ships to take it.

Now add in 2 other races that each have modified rules for production (think the races in Starcraft 2 and how they are similar but unique in how they go about it) and you have not only a fine single player game but a great multiplayer setup. The campaign unfortunately only features the humans.

If you liked Eufloria, Mushroom Wars, or Blue Libra 2, there's definitely something new to like here.

I bought this game while on sale, and with a coupon, which made it around $2-3. I figured that I would give it a try, and I am glad I did. Though this game can be very frustrating, especially when the difficulty increases a lot (Was stuck on levels 7-14 for weeks), it's a very fun game to play. It has multiplayer, skirmish, and campaign.
In campaign, your goal is to capture all of the planets, the enemy's home planets, or hold the 'flag' planet, using your force/army. You can upgrade your character/force, and gain money/energy.
In skirmish, you face 1-3 enemies and do the same as campaign, except here you can play as any character and can spend time practicing if you're having troubles on a level.
I have not played multiplayer on this game, but I plan to soon!
Overall, I would recommend this to anyone who likes a good, challenging game, and has patience and time on hand.
Pros:
-Multiplayer (haven't tried it)
-Challenging
-Good graphics and color
-Fun, upbeat music
-Multiple characters to play
-Campaign
-Skirmish
Cons:
-Difficulty increases a lot after level 6
-Robots are harder to play as
-Almost sure it's impossible to complete the campaign, at least for me
